messages: b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:09): where can I find information about how vendors other than Mozilla use the Public Suffix List?
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (10:09): http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-svg-wg/2009JanMar/0306.html o_O
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (10:10): thought it was widely known people used VML/SVG to do graphics nowadays
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (10:11): Yeah! We hate SVG!
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (10:12): Yeah, HTML has enough capabilities of doing declarative 2d graphics already: <table> :)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:14): Do the HTML5 folks hate SVG more than they hate accessibility?
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (10:15): That's a tough call. Definitely hate it more than internationalization.
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (10:15): Also fun reading: http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-xhtml2/2009Mar/0101.html
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (10:16): "re-introduce BR, marking as deprecated, and point out that for accessibility, is much better to use L"
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:16): 4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b: I'd love to see a technical explanation for that one
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:19): has anyone tried the Google SVG stuff yet? do they do it in the same DOM as HTML or in an iframed XML DOM?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:19): if the former, what tricks do they pull to make it work in WebKit?
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (10:25): doesn't WebKit allow it to work in the DOM?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:26): 4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b: it doesn't render in WebKit for me
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:26): livedom.validator.nu works with SVG only in Firefox and Opera
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:27): no idea why

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:45): FWIW I think renaming <header> to <hgroup> or something similar is a very good idea because I have come across a number of people who think that <header> is either like <hn> without the n or like <footer>
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:46): Sure it is more ugly but it will also be used right more often
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:46): And HTML is already pretty ugly
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:46): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: what about renaming <footer> into <contentinfo>?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:47): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: my gut reaction is agreeing with renaming to <hgroup>
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (10:48): hgroup sounds like hcard or hcalendar
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (10:48): wonders why hgroup, not headergroup
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:48): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: head*ing*group surely?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:48): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: I'm less sure about <footer>. The issues there seem more aesthetic
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:48): isn't at all attached to <hgroup>
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:48): Just not <heading>
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:49): (this is another reason to rename it)
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (10:50): lets call them <top> and <bottom>
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:50): is it OK if I change html5lib tests according to Hixie's forward-looking IRC statements about foster parenting?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:50): 4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b: my mother's site has stuff that is semantically <footer> but it's above content
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (10:51): I'm not too convinced about some of the structural elements. E.g. I find <article> quite confusing and I'm missing <content> or <main>
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (10:52): I haven't quite figured out how to explain that properly though
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:52): <realbody>
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:53): I don't really understand <content>
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:53): What would <content> be on a blog?
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (10:54): it would be the bit under the primary heading and navigation
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:54): In those cases <article> seems pretty obvious
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (10:54): and above the copyright and other links section
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (10:54): <article> is only for a single article
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:54): So the content ould be everything not in <nav> <header> or <footer>?
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (10:55): or <aside>, yes, that leaves content :)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:55): <aside> is content
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (10:55): well, <aside> is both
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (10:55): it can easily be ignored
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:55): Oh wait, Hixie has this totally screwy definition of <aside>
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (10:56): content is all the articles on my blog frontpage
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:56): There is no way that <aside> should contain sidebars for navigation or anything like that
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:56): it just makes no sense
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (10:56): it's the actual content of the page, you might want to jump to it
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (10:57): you typically want to style it
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:57): Because it means that there are two totally different usecases for <aside>
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:57): One: for pullout boxes containing content
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (10:57): oh, I thought you were talking about <content> still
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:57): Two: For structural elements of the page
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:58): Only number One corresponds to any reasonable defenition of <aside>
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:58): I guess <content> makes some sense, but I think you could do without it
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (10:58): no, a list of blogs, the wordpress sidebar, etc. those things are <aside>
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:59): 4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b: That is defenition Two. The one which makes no sense
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (10:59): it makes sense to me
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:00): How is a list of blogs an aside? What is it an aside to?
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (11:00): aside to the main purpose of the page?
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (11:00): it's sidebar thingie, an aside
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:00): <sidebar> makes some sense
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:00): aside, not as much
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:01): And often these things are not asides to the main purpose of the page
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (11:01): <aside> also means "apart", "to the side"
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:02): Do you agree that <aside> covers two entirely different concepts?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:02): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: I'll also update the tests for the new AAA
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (11:02): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea, I agree the concepts are slightly different, but not too much

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:03): 4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b: I don't really see any overlap between the two use cases. One is a content box that is out of the main flow of the content. The other is site stucture
5b67d980ae4c3c82251106e26913ce67 (11:03): Isn't <article><aside> usable for case 1, and <body><aside> for case 2?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:04): 5b67d980ae4c3c82251106e26913ce67: If you want to force all content to be wrapped in <article> elements
5b67d980ae4c3c82251106e26913ce67 (11:06): I think it'd be handy if there was some place with screenshots of websites and a global outline of new elements you could use
5b67d980ae4c3c82251106e26913ce67 (11:06): Before we authors just start inventing our own use for some of the new elements, because we are too lazy to read the spec
5b67d980ae4c3c82251106e26913ce67 (11:07): Something like http://www.alistapart.com/articles/previewofhtml5 but with 'real' sites
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (11:08): can you make the <canvas> app that lets us do that? :)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (11:09): remembers why he avoids #css
5b67d980ae4c3c82251106e26913ce67 (11:10): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: and why's that? :)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (11:10): 5b67d980ae4c3c82251106e26913ce67: They're a bunch of idiots, basically.
5b67d980ae4c3c82251106e26913ce67 (11:10): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: well thank you, cause I'm an idiot too. And we idiots are going to use the new stuff you come up with in here
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (11:11): 5b67d980ae4c3c82251106e26913ce67: I don't like being told, "the wey i see it , you should just shut up and start learning something"
5b67d980ae4c3c82251106e26913ce67 (11:12): Right, you lost me

4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (11:12): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554, btw, there's huge amount of Scottish people in the Netherland. They were all hopping around in their kilts in Amsterdam last night. Apparently there's a football match coming up between our countries.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (11:13): I guess I'm meant to say "We'll kick your ass", but I really don't care for football.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (11:13): assumes a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 isn't talking about W3C #css
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (11:13): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: No, freenode #css

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (11:13): 5b67d980ae4c3c82251106e26913ce67: By the way, http:/ 5b67d980ae4c3c82251106e26913ce67oetmer.nl/irc-logs/css/20090327 says "-#c-ss" at the top which seems odd :-)
5b67d980ae4c3c82251106e26913ce67 (11:15): That's part of me trying to prove my idiotness
5b67d980ae4c3c82251106e26913ce67 (11:15): Working quite well
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (11:15): 5b67d980ae4c3c82251106e26913ce67: You rule.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (11:15): I think the existence of the irc-logs service is proof of nonidiotness :-)
5b67d980ae4c3c82251106e26913ce67 (11:16): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: that's just because you haven't seen the code :)
5b67d980ae4c3c82251106e26913ce67 (11:16): Are these 'markup tutorials' thingies requested before?
5b67d980ae4c3c82251106e26913ce67 (11:16): Is that the cookbook DanC is working on
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (11:21): http://pastebin.ca/1373856
5b67d980ae4c3c82251106e26913ce67 (11:24): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: that's a nice pill to swallow for a lot of developers, which takes some time
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (11:25): wonders why he read that
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (11:25): stuff like that drives me away from everyday forums, which is bad, since it's good to know what people want
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:26): hmm. it seems my frameset-ok code may suck
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (11:29): It's the elitism of, "I'm right, you're wrong. You go learn.", when in fact they are wrong that really pisses me off.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:29): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: Calm dowwn, calm down
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (11:29): slaps b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:29): (that is best read in a liverpudlan accent)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (11:29): :P

4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (11:33): pondered whether he should go in to say that a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 is right (and if they didn't buy it I'd just point to some CSS spec that carries my name :p )
5b67d980ae4c3c82251106e26913ce67 (11:35): 4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b: a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 can waste his time by calling them idiots (elitism?), but you should know better ;)
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (11:36): 5b67d980ae4c3c82251106e26913ce67, I'm just amusing myself with the thought
5b67d980ae4c3c82251106e26913ce67 (11:37): More people should just be satisfied with the thoughts alone :)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (11:38): I'm now getting told about what is and isn't valid HTML 5 by someone who says they aren't that familiar with HTML 5.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:39): I'm not sure what that is surprising
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:43): have browsers started accepting unitless lengths in the standards mode? due to SVG?
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (11:44): Opera used quirks mode parsing for SVG for a short while
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:44): so is the #css stuff only about quirks mode?
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (11:44): I managed to get that fixed...
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:46): whoa! the new AAA makes so much more sense than the old one for <!DOCTYPE html><p><b><i><u></p> <p>X
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:48): Hixie: seems like the old one was rather silly here
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:48): goes test what WebKit does
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:48): WebKit indeed does it the old way
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:49): new AAA FTW!
